episodeTitle: Go, Chopper Man! Protect the TV Station on the Beach
episodeTitleJapanese: 出動チョッパーマン！守れ渚のＴＶ局
episodeTitleRomanized: Shutsudō Choppāman! Mamore Nagisa no Terebi Kyoku
episodeTitleFunimationDub: Chopperman to the Rescue! Protect the TV Station by the Shore!
description: In this comedic filler special, Chopper Man and his sidekick Namifia face off against the villain Dr. Usodabada, who attempts to take over a TV station. The episode features wrestling matches, mecha battles, and parodies of the Straw Hat crew as Chopper Man fights to obtain a rare collectible and save the day.

events.title: Shopan's Debut
events.description: Shopan, a television anchor and commentator, appears for the first time as she prepares to commentate on the wrestling match between Chopper Man and Dr. Usodabada. She is based on real-life Fuji TV announcer Yoko Shono.
events.significance: Introduces a new character who serves as the news reporter and commentator in the Chopper Man universe, adding a media/public perspective to the parody superhero story.

events.title: Kazeno Minoru's Debut
events.description: Kazeno Minoru, a professional wrestler and sports commentator, makes his first appearance alongside Shopan as a commentator for the match. He is based on real Japanese wrestler Minoru Suzuki who also voices the character.
events.significance: Introduces a skilled wrestler character who will later intervene in the match to defeat the villain, demonstrating strong moral principles against Usodabada's blackmail tactics.

events.title: Chopper Man and Namifia's Financial Crisis
events.description: The episode opens with Chopper Man and his sidekick Namifia struggling with money problems, setting up the motivation for Chopper Man's involvement in the upcoming events.
events.significance: Establishes the comedic setup for the episode and provides character motivation that parodies typical superhero stories where heroes are driven by noble causes rather than financial needs.

events.title: Dr. Usodabada's Scheme to Take Over TV Station
events.description: Dr. Usodabada, the primary villain, devises a plan to take over the TV station and broadcast his demands to gain fame. He also aims to recruit a new crew to replace his ineffective henchmen Sanjirops and Zorokiller.
events.significance: Sets up the main conflict of the episode and drives the plot forward, showcasing the villain's motivations and introducing the central threat.

events.title: Chopper Man Joins for the Collectible
events.description: Chopper Man decides to get involved in the conflict not out of heroic duty, but because he wants to obtain a rare Air Force C-Max collectible item that is somehow connected to the TV station event.
events.significance: Provides comedic subversion of superhero tropes by having the hero motivated by personal desire for a toy rather than justice, consistent with Chopper Man's established obsession with giant robots and collectibles.

events.title: Wrestling Match Begins
events.description: A wrestling match begins between Chopper Man and Dr. Usodabada, commentated by Shopan and Kazeno Minoru. The match serves as the first confrontation between hero and villain in the episode.
events.significance: Initiates the physical conflict of the episode in a comedic wrestling format, parodying both superhero battles and professional wrestling, with commentary adding a sporting event atmosphere.

events.title: Dr. Usodabada Takes TV Station Hostage
events.description: Dr. Usodabada uses blackmail tactics and takes the TV station hostage, including Shopan and the other staff, escalating the threat and demonstrating his villainous methods.
events.significance: Raises the stakes of the conflict and triggers Kazeno Minoru's moral outrage, leading to his intervention in the fight.

events.title: Kazeno Minoru Defeats Usodabada in Wrestling
events.description: Angered by Dr. Usodabada's blackmail and hostage-taking, professional wrestler Kazeno Minoru voluntarily enters the wrestling match and decisively defeats the villain with his superior wrestling skills.
events.significance: Demonstrates Kazeno Minoru's moral character and fighting prowess, while providing the first defeat of the villain. Shows that even in a parody setting, characters stand up for what's right.

events.title: Mecha Battle Begins
events.description: Following the wrestling match, Dr. Usodabada escalates the conflict by deploying a giant mecha (likely involving the Giant Luffy Bomber), and Chopper Man must face him in a mecha battle.
events.significance: Shifts the genre from wrestling parody to mecha/robot battle parody, showcasing the episode's blend of different action genres and Chopper Man's love for giant robots coming into play.

events.title: Chopper Man Wins Mecha Battle
events.description: Chopper Man defeats Dr. Usodabada in the mecha battle, using his skills and possibly his signature Kyuun Spark or Chopper Violence attacks. The villain is sent flying in typical One Piece fashion.
events.significance: Concludes the main conflict with Chopper Man's victory, reinforcing his role as the hero despite his initially selfish motivations. The 'sent flying' defeat is a direct parody of One Piece battle conclusions.

events.title: Chopper Man Achieves Celebrity Status
events.description: Following his victory over Dr. Usodabada, Chopper Man achieves celebrity status, likely through the TV station's broadcast of his heroic deeds, completing his character arc for the episode.
events.significance: Provides a comedic resolution where Chopper Man gets both recognition and presumably access to his desired collectible, subverting and then reinforcing superhero tropes about recognition and reward.

themes.description: The episode parodies superhero conventions by presenting the Straw Hat crew as both heroes and villains in an over-the-top comedic setting.
themes.symbolism: The Chopper Man character represents a satirical take on sentai heroes and tokusatsu shows popular in Japanese media.

themes.description: One Piece parodies itself by reimagining its main characters in exaggerated roles, with Chopper as a cute but bumbling hero and other crew members as incompetent villains.
themes.symbolism: The episode serves as a lighthearted break from the main story, allowing the series to poke fun at its own conventions.

characterSpotlights.development: Chopper Man is portrayed as a hero with selfish motivations (wanting a collectible) who nonetheless saves the day, demonstrating that even imperfect heroes can do good.
keyActions: Decides to join the conflict for a collectible
Defeats Dr. Usodabada in mecha battle

characterSpotlights.development: Dr. Usodabada serves as the primary villain, attempting to gain fame through nefarious means but ultimately being defeated through both wrestling and mecha combat.
keyActions: Plans to take over TV station

characterSpotlights.development: Kazeno Minoru demonstrates strong moral principles by intervening when he witnesses villainous behavior, showing that even side characters uphold justice.

mangaDifferences.difference: This entire episode is anime-original filler content based on the Chopper Man parody concept from One Piece Blue: Grand Data File. It does not adapt any manga chapter.
mangaDifferences.mangaReference: One Piece Blue: Grand Data File (concept origin)

trivia.fact: This episode aired on December 23, 2007, as a Christmas-themed special filler episode in Japan.

Shopan is based on real-life Fuji TV announcer Yoko Shono, who also voices the character. The character name references Shono's professional nickname and her late-night talk show that aired from 2007-2008.
Kazeno Minoru is based on and voiced by real Japanese professional wrestler Minoru Suzuki, known for his work in New Japan Pro-Wrestling and other promotions.
The episode features custom eyecatchers featuring Chopper Man, different from the standard One Piece eyecatchers.
This episode had a TV rating of 8.9%, ranking 5th in its timeslot when it aired.
Episode 336 aired during the period when One Piece had stopped using ending themes, with this episode using only the opening 'Jungle P' and no ending song.

The Chopper Man concept originated from a yonkoma (4-panel comic strip) in One Piece Blue: Grand Data File and has appeared in multiple formats including episodes 279 and 336, video games, and spin-off manga.
